title: Behind-the-scenes of Shaun The Sheep movie Farmageddon
text:

When a young alien crashes on Mossy Bottom Farm with no idea how to get home there is only one hero who can save the day... Shaun the Sheep.

His first film, 2015’s Shaun the Sheep Movie, took £100million at the box office and gained 49 award nominations across the globe, including an Oscar nod.

So Aardman Animations have decided to take their much-loved character on an intergalactic adventure.

A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon has the woolly star trying to shepherd alien Lu-La back to her home planet.

This rocket-fuelled journey of excitement, emotion and fun was created at a small studio in Bristol.

When we visit, we are first greeted by a giant Wallace, one of Aardman’s first successes who with trusty – and much wiser – sidekick Gromit, debuted in 1989’s A Grand Day Out.

Our first stop is the set of Mossingham Supermarket, where Shaun takes Lu-La for a snack. Computers create so much cinema these days but not here.

(Image: Handout)

They use old-fashioned stop motion where characters are moved tiny amounts between individually photographed frames, which are played back at speed to create the illusion of movement.

“It’s a lot of hard work,” says animator, Carmen Bromfield-Mason.

“We had over 20 animators working at full capacity and we were expected to make, on average, two seconds of animation a day.

“It doesn’t sound like very much. But everybody just keeps going and when you have worked like that for about a year and a half, you end up with a feature film.”

Most challenging for animators is to make the characters show emotions, particularly in a film without dialogue.

Carmen explains: “Shaun doesn’t have eyebrows but eyelids make a difference to show if he’s angry or sad.”

(Image: Handout)

(Image: Handout)

And the animators also use old-fashioned techniques to create water and fire. Even the bins are made out of cola cans.

Carmen says: “People use cling film for water and bubbles are glass beads.

“Although we’re a huge company, we keep things low-tech. It’s the closest thing to magic that I can do.”

Next, we head to the puppet-making studio. While I desperately grapple with plasticine in a bid to make my own Lu-La, Will Harding, who has worked in the business for 15 years, makes it look easy.

He says: “Models can take anywhere between a couple of weeks and a month to make.

“We do quite a lot of research into the materials and test them to see if they work on camera. So, for Shaun’s wool we actually had to stiffen the material as we didn’t want it to become too fluffy.”

The film has already been compared to Stranger Things and ET. Producer Paul Kewley admits: “We love all those references, but, we want to be unique and feel like Farmageddon is its own thing.

“My favourite new character is Lu-La – she is engaging, warm and exciting.

(Image: Handout)

(Image: © 2018 Aardman Animations Limited and Studiocanal S.A.S.)

“It’s really hard finding actors for characters that don’t have much dialogue and a lot of actors who have tried it found it harder than they expected.

“Justin Fletcher and John Sparkes, who play Shaun and Bitzer, are just brilliant. You tell them something and they come up with the sounds. It’s an extraordinary thing to see”

Yes, that’s children’s TV superstar Justin Fletcher – aka Mr Tumble – who voices (bleats) Shaun.

These aren’t the only sounds in the film which are unique – with the soundtrack being headed up by big names such as Kylie and The Vaccines.

And look out for a few starry cameos. Paul says: “Joe Sugg agreed to play the pizza boy and is fantastic.

“We’ve also got Professor Brian Cox, who does a cameo.”

Directors Will Becher and Rich Phelan, agree the inspiration for the storyline –apart from the alien presumably – comes from “their own lives”.

Rich says despite the aliens it has a much more human meaning. He adds: “The core of the story is just about two best friends having an adventure.”

A Shaun The Sheep Movie: Farmageddon is out in cinemas now.
description: The family-friendly adventure came together at a small studio in Bristol
